title: Do novel authors know all vocabularies? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, absolutely not. You should, of course, have a solid working knowledge of language—that doesn’t just mean vocabulary, but grammar, spelling, etc. Think of it this way: would you hire someone to be a programmer if they didn’t know programming language, couldn’t type, and had no logic skills? NO. Writers have a toolbox. That toolbox is full of words, grammar, and spelling. Having said that, you don’t have to know every word in existence. I’m 57 years old and I still run across words I’ve never seen before. The trick is this: look up their meaning, and learn how that word is used in a sentence. Then you’ve added it to your “toolbox.” You may or may not ever need it, but it’s good to have it. I hope that helps!

Usually not. In fact, most authors of fiction have weak vocabularies and not very much knowledge in the disciplines. In fact, it is unfortunate that people are guided to read novels to acquire an English Vocabulary, because novels rely upon modifiers such as Adjectives and Adverbs, both of which serve very little use in daily conversation. People who read more nonfiction develop a much more complete vocabulary. If you want a way of measuring an author’s vocabulary, you can get an idea by the vocabulary of the book reviewers. For example, if you study book reviewers for “Harry Potter” novels by J. K. Rowling, you are going to see many reviews like; “I love this book!”; but that 4 letter vocabulary is about as advanced as it gets.
